Image 1 of / 64 64 PHOTOS: A visual history of ZZ Top
Members of the Moving Sidewalks were drafted into the Army, so Gibbons recruited bassist Dusty Hill (center) and drummer Frank Beard (right) from Dallas band American Blues. They were at this stage NOT sharp dressed men.
Click through to see ZZ Top in their pre-beard days... less PHOTOS: A visual history of ZZ Top
Members of the Moving Sidewalks were drafted into the Army, so Gibbons recruited bassist Dusty Hill (center) and drummer Frank Beard (right) from Dallas band American Blues. ... more Image 2 of 64 Billy Gibbons was performing when he was a student at Lee High School. Billy Gibbons was performing when he was a student at Lee High School. Photo: File Image 3 of 64 In the late 1960s Gibbons (far right) formed the psychedelic rock band the Moving Sidewalks with (from left) Dan Mitchell, Tom Moore, and Don Summers. In the late 1960s Gibbons (far right) formed the psychedelic rock band the Moving Sidewalks with (from left) Dan Mitchell, Tom Moore, and Don Summers. Image 4 of 64 In 2012 the Moving Sidewalks music was reissued as "The Complete Collection."
In 2012 the Moving Sidewalks music was reissued as "The Complete Collection."
Image 5 of 64 Austin's 13th Floor Elevators were fronted by Roky Erickson. The psych rock legends were a strong influence on the Moving Sidewalks. Austin's 13th Floor Elevators were fronted by Roky Erickson. The psych rock legends were a strong influence on the Moving Sidewalks. Photo: Ben DeSoto, HC Staff Image 6 of 64 Gibbons and "Pearly Gates" early in their relationship. He credits the guitar's tone with helping establish the sound of ZZ Top. King was cited by Gibbons in Rolling Stone as his favorite guitarist. He also picked King's "Singin' the Blues" as one of his 10 favorite blues recordings. Double back: Blues great B.B. King was cited by Gibbons in Rolling Stone as his favorite guitarist. He also picked King's "Singin' the Blues" as one of his 10 favorite blues recordings. Photo: Denise Truscello, Getty Images For PR Plus Image 8 of 64 ZZ Top's first LP with its endlessly cryptic title. What could it mean??? Recorded in Tyler Texas and released in 1971. Bluesy and appropriately full of adult themes that would become a band calling card. ZZ Top's first LP with its endlessly cryptic title. What could it mean??? Recorded in Tyler Texas and released in 1971. Bluesy and appropriately full of adult themes that would become a band calling card. Image 9 of 64 Double back: Dusty Hill occasionally played with Houston blues great Lightnin' Hopkins. Double back: Dusty Hill occasionally played with Houston blues great Lightnin' Hopkins. ZZ Top comes out of the woods with a Donegal and specs (Gibbons, left), a goatee and Akubra (Hill, center), and a 'stache and mullet (Beard). More from the early '70s. ZZ Top comes out of the woods with a Donegal and specs (Gibbons, left), a goatee and Akubra (Hill, center), and a 'stache and mullet (Beard). Photo: Michael Ochs Archives Image 13 of 64 Swimming in murky blues rock. Recorded in Tyler, released in 1972, the band opted not to go with "ZZ Top's Second Album" as a title. "Rio Grande Mud" contained the band's first charting single in "Francine" and the concert staple "Just Got Paid." less Swimming in murky blues rock. "That little ol' band from Texas" was not to be little for much longer. Beards of a feather. And a dog. "That little ol' band from Texas" was not to be little for much longer. Photo: handout Image 15 of 64 The band's breakthrough album, released in 1973. It had a hit in "La Grange" and future concert standards in "Waitin' for the Bus/Jesus Just Left Chicago" and "Beer Drinkers and Hell Raisers." The band's breakthrough album, released in 1973. It had a hit in "La Grange" and future concert standards in "Waitin' for the Bus/Jesus Just Left Chicago" and "Beer Drinkers and Hell Raisers." Image 16 of 64 Double back: The guitar riff to "La Grange" was a tip to John Lee Hooker's "Boogie Chillun," though the copyright holder for Hooker's song filed a suit claiming it was infringement. ZZ Top would prevail in court. less Double back: The guitar riff to "La Grange" was a tip to John Lee Hooker's "Boogie Chillun," though the copyright holder for Hooker's song filed a suit claiming it was infringement. It included the concert warhorse "Tush," as well as "Balinese," about a nightclub in Galveston. Released in 1975, "Fandango!" was a half live/half studio album. Live and bedazzled. Photo: Jerry Click, Houston Chronicle Image 23 of 64 "Tejas" was released in 1976. It was not among the band's better works. After a three year break, they returned with big beards and "Deguello." The album included staples "I'm Bad, I'm Nationwide," "Cheap Sunglasses" and a cover of Isaac Hayes and David Porter's "Thank You." less "Tejas" was released in 1976. Some success can be attributed to the songs themselves. Some can be attributed to the band's savvy use of videos on MTV, which would prove to be a short-lived symbiotic relationship. less Released in 1983, "Eliminator" sold more than 10 million copies thanks to hits "Gimme All Your Lovin'," "Legs" and "Got Me Under Pressure." He started working with ZZ Top in 2007. Rick Rubin only looks like a member of ZZ Top. He's a producer who worked with Beastie Boys, Slayer and Johnny Cash. He started working with ZZ Top in 2007. What to do? Where to go? Photo: Ross Halfin Image 48 of 64 With Rubin they made "La Futura," the first ZZ album in nearly a decade. The single "I Gotsta Get Paid" was a reimagined version of Houston hip-hop classic "25 Lighters" by DJ DMD with Lil Keke and Fat Pat. Double back: A legendary figure in Houston hip-hop thanks to "25 Lighters," DJ DMD has turned his attention toward Christian hip-hop. Image 50 of 64 Crossover! Crossover! Photo: Ross Halfin Image 51 of 64 And back to the road, where the band spends much of its time. The futura is now. And back to the road, where the band spends much of its time. The futura is now. Joan Jett and the Blackhearts have played "Tush." Photo: Christopher Polk, Getty Images For Clear Channel Image 57 of 64 Rabble rousing country star Hank Williams Jr. has done "Blue Jean Blues." Rabble rousing country star Hank Williams Jr. has done "Blue Jean Blues." Image 58 of 64 While next gen rabble rousing country singer Hank III has done "Fearless Boogie." (An underappreciated ZZ song.) While next gen rabble rousing country singer Hank III has done "Fearless Boogie." (An underappreciated ZZ song.) In addition to sitting on park benches and playing blistering prog metal, Georgia band Mastodon covered "Just Got Paid." Photo: Cindy Frey Image 60 of 64 Fellow beard enthusiast and country singer Jamey Johnson has recorded "La Grange." Fellow beard enthusiast and country singer Jamey Johnson has recorded "La Grange." While clean-cut country star Brad Paisley has put his stamp on "Sharp Dressed Man." "No word yet as to when there will be new music. In its 46th year, the band continues to tour for much of the year. "Same three guys," Gibbons says in concert, "same three chords. "No word yet as to when there will be new music. Photo: Ross Halfin Image 63 of 64 Dusty Hill, Frank Beard and Billy Gibbons of ZZ Top perform at the Fayette County Fairgrounds on September 5, 2015 in La Grange, Texas. (Photo by Gary Miller/Getty Images) Dusty Hill, Frank Beard and Billy Gibbons of ZZ Top perform at the Fayette County Fairgrounds on September 5, 2015 in La Grange, Texas. (Photo by Gary Miller/Getty Images) Photo: Gary Miller, File / Getty Image 64 of 64 47 years ago this week the ZZ Top story began in Beaumont 1 / 64 Back to Gallery A handful of old-timers in Beaumont were witnesses to rock and roll history 47 years ago this week and they likely don't remember a darn thing about the night.
But what they saw changed the course of Texas rock for decades.
On this date in February 1970, ZZ Top played at a Knights of Columbus Hall on old U.S. 90, a gig booked by Beaumont radio personality Al Caldwell of KLVI, who would later also broadcast the band's first recordings.
This would be the band’s first show together with their now-iconic lineup of Billy Gibbons, Dusty Hill and Frank Beard installed. Gibbons started the band in late 1969 and the pieces soon came together.
FARRAH HAD IT: The hidden Houston connection to a classic R&B radio hit
Houston fans will get to see ZZ Top back in action next month as the band is slated to play RodeoHouston on Tuesday, March 21 at NRG Stadium. The band turned in a raucous set last weekend at Super Bowl Live festivities in downtown Houston.
Back in 2015 bassist Hill told Chron.com via email that he had to borrow a pivotal piece of stage equipment to play the show.
"I had to borrow a bass for that gig. I didn't actually own one. It was the Knights of Columbus Hall and though I didn't meet any knights or royalty, there were a lot of cool people who came out to hear us play," Hill wrote. "And so it began..."
It's not every day that ZZ Top's Billy Gibbons wonders over to Wall Street, but he did today to help promote a benefit concert Friday night in New York. The group Wall Street Rocks is holding a concert to raise money for military veterans and first responders. Gibbons joins other performers at the event, including John Popper of Blues Traveler, and Matt Sorum of Guns N' Roses. The group Wall Street Rocks is a collaboration of employees in the financial, technology and entertainment industries. The concert is being held at the Highline Ballroom in New York. Video provided by TheStreet
Media: Brandpoint In those early days they also played a handful of proms and sanctioned high school parties, probably warping hundreds of young Texans for decades to come.
THE VERY FIRST TOP: The story of ZZ Top’s first album
A picture of the band at the Little Cypress-Mauriceville High School prom in Orange made the rounds years back over on Reddit. It’s probably the closest picture one will find of the band when it was just a few months old. A “yearbook club error” had them billed as “Zee Zee Top” in the photo.
A year or so after that first gig in Beaumont the band released its debut album simply titled “ZZ Top’s First Album” on U.K. label London Records.
